“20190416223046” is the date and time of the key’s creation, which was 2019-04-16 22:30:46.
“Headless” systems are configured to operate without a monitor (the “head”) keyboard, and mouse. They are usually controlled over a network connection.

“Key management” is a software term that means “Safely and securely getting the right credentials from remote and local computers into the right directories–usually, but not always, on your local computer–in order to use software to run commands between computers”.

“There’s no such thing as a free lunch”, as the saying goes, and that holds true here. If the Supervisor is running as a non-root user, any processes that it supervises will be run as the same user; any values that the process might specify via pkg_svc_user and pkg_svc_group are essentially ignored. Furthermore, any files written out by the service during its operation are also owned by that same user.

(Beta only) A filter string to be used as the filter string for a Stackdriver Monitoring TimeSeries.list API call. This filter is used to select a specific TimeSeries for the purpose of autoscaling and to determine whether the metric is exporting per-instance or per-group data. You can only use the AND operator for joining selectors. You can only use direct equality comparison operator (=) without any functions for each selector. You can specify the metric in both the filter string and in the metric field. However, if specified in both places, the metric must be identical. The monitored resource type determines what kind of values are expected for the metric. If it is a gce_instance, the autoscaler expects the metric to include a separate TimeSeries for each instance in a group. In such a case, you cannot filter on resource labels. If the resource type is any other value, the autoscaler expects this metric to contain values that apply to the entire autoscaled instance group and resource label filtering can be performed to point autoscaler at the correct TimeSeries to scale upon. This is called a per-group metric for the purpose of autoscaling. If not specified, the type defaults to gce_instance. You should provide a filter that is selective enough to pick just one TimeSeries for the autoscaled group or for each of the instances (if you are using gce_instance resource type). If multiple TimeSeries are returned upon the query execution, the autoscaler will sum their respective values to obtain its scaling value.
(Beta only) Configuration for the PodSecurityPolicy feature.
(Beta only) Configure logging on this health check.
(Beta only) Describes the configuration of a trigger that creates a build whenever a GitHub event is received.

(Beta only) If scaling is based on a per-group metric value that represents the total amount of work to be done or resource usage, set this value to an amount assigned for a single instance of the scaled group. The autoscaler will keep the number of instances proportional to the value of this metric, the metric itself should not change value due to group resizing. For example, a good metric to use with the target is pubsub.googleapis.com/subscription/num_undelivered_messages or a custom metric exporting the total number of requests coming to your instances. A bad example would be a metric exporting an average or median latency, since this value can’t include a chunk assignable to a single instance, it could be better used with utilization_target instead.
(Beta only) If you use sole-tenant nodes for your workloads, you can use the node group autoscaler to automatically manage the sizes of your node groups.

(Beta only) Indicates whether or not this load balancer can be used as a collector for packet mirroring. To prevent mirroring loops, instances behind this load balancer will not have their traffic mirrored even if a PacketMirroring rule applies to them. This can only be set to true for load balancers that have their loadBalancingScheme set to INTERNAL.
(Beta only) Labels to apply to this VpnTunnel.
(Beta only) Labels to apply to this address. A list of key->value pairs.
(Beta only) Labels to apply to this forwarding rule. A list of key->value pairs.
(Beta only) Resource policies applied to this disk for automatic snapshot creations.

(Beta only) Specifies if this is a managed reverse lookup zone. If true, Cloud DNS will resolve reverse lookup queries using automatically configured records for VPC resources. This only applies to networks listed under private_visibility_config.
(Beta only) The fingerprint used for optimistic locking of this resource. Used internally during updates.
(Beta only) The interface ID of the VPN gateway with which this VPN tunnel is associated.
(Beta only) The interface ID of the external VPN gateway to which this VPN tunnel is connected.
(Beta only) The name of the encryption key that is stored in Google Cloud KMS.
(Beta only) The presence for this field indicates that outbound forwarding is enabled for this zone. The value of this field contains the set of destinations to forward to.
(Beta only) The presence of this field indicates that DNS Peering is enabled for this zone. The value of this field contains the network to peer with.
(Beta only) The presence of this field indicates that this zone is backed by Service Directory. The value of this field contains information related to the namespace associated with the zone.

(Beta only) The purpose of the resource. This field can be either PRIVATE or INTERNAL_HTTPS_LOAD_BALANCER. A subnetwork with purpose set to INTERNAL_HTTPS_LOAD_BALANCER is a user-created subnetwork that is reserved for Internal HTTP(S) Load Balancing. If unspecified, the purpose defaults to PRIVATE. If set to INTERNAL_HTTPS_LOAD_BALANCER you must also set the role.

(Beta only) The role of subnetwork. Currently, this field is only used when purpose = INTERNAL_HTTPS_LOAD_BALANCER. The value can be set to ACTIVE or BACKUP. An ACTIVE subnetwork is one that is currently being used for Internal HTTP(S) Load Balancing. A BACKUP subnetwork is one that is ready to be promoted to ACTIVE or is currently draining.
(Beta only) The server binding policy for nodes using this template. Determines where the nodes should restart following a maintenance event.
(Beta only) The timeout for new network connections to hosts.
(Beta only) URL of the VPN gateway with which this VPN tunnel is associated. This must be used if a High Availability VPN gateway resource is created.

(Beta only) URL of the peer side HA GCP VPN gateway to which this VPN tunnel is connected. If provided, the VPN tunnel will automatically use the same vpn_gateway_interface ID in the peer GCP VPN gateway.
(Beta only) URL of the peer side external VPN gateway to which this VPN tunnel is connected.

(For those who know the Microsoft Windows API: :read corresponds to GENERIC_READ; :write corresponds to GENERIC_WRITE; :read_execute corresponds to GENERIC_READ and GENERIC_EXECUTE; :modify corresponds to GENERIC_WRITE, GENERIC_READ, GENERIC_EXECUTE, and DELETE; :full_control corresponds to GENERIC_ALL, which allows a user to change the owner and other metadata about a file.)
trans-unit.target: (Para los que conocen la API de Microsoft Windows: :read corresponde a GENERIC_READ ; :write corresponde a GENERIC_WRITE ; :read_execute corresponde a GENERIC_READ y GENERIC_EXECUTE ; :modify corresponde a GENERIC_WRITE , GENERIC_READ , GENERIC_EXECUTE , y DELETE ; :full_control corresponde a GENERIC_ALL , que permite a un usuario cambiar el propietario y otros metadatos sobre un archivo).

(user, client, etc.) has read access, as determined by ACL settings. This affects all searches. 32-bit versions of Chef Infra Client (12.8 and earlier) and 64-bit versions of Chef Infra Client (12.9 and later) generally behave the same in this situation, with one exception: it is only possible to read and write from a redirected registry location using chef-client version 12.9 (and later).

64-bit versions of Microsoft Windows have a 32-bit compatibility layer in the registry that reflects and redirects certain keys (and their values) into specific locations (or logical views) of the registry hive.
trans-unit.target: Las versiones de 64 bits de Microsoft Windows tienen una capa de compatibilidad de 32 bits en el registro que refleja y redirige ciertas claves (y sus valores)a ubicaciones específicas (o vistas lógicas)de la colmena del registro.

trans-unit.source: 64-bit versions of Microsoft Windows have a 32-bit compatibility layer that redirects attempts by 32-bit application to access the System32 directory to a different location. Starting with chef-client version 12.9, the 32-bit version of the chef-client is subject to the file redirection policy.
trans-unit.target: Las versiones de 64 bits de Microsoft Windows tienen una capa de compatibilidad de 32 bits que redirige los intentos de una aplicación de 32 bits para acceder al directorio System32 a una ubicación diferente. A partir de la versión 12.9 del chef-cliente, la versión de 32 bits del chef-cliente está sujeta a la política de redirección de archivos.

resource-specific matchers, which operate directly on the resource, are used with it, and tend to be highly customized to the auditing needs of the resource
Tiered (machines configured for front-end and back-end, with a single back-end and load-balancing on the front-end, as required)
universal matchers, which operate on the properties of the resource, are used with its, and tend to be very generic, operating on text, numbers, and lists

Chef Compliance is Chef Software’s premium audit and remediation content offering announced in 2020. The standalone Chef Compliance Server was an earlier security product and is now deprecated. The Chef Compliance Server’s end-of-life date was December 31, 2018. Chef Automate 2 has all of the functionality of Chef Compliance Server and also includes newer out-of-the-box compliance profiles, an improved compliance scanner with total cloud scanning functionality, better visualizations, role-based access control and many other features not found in Chef Compliance Server.
Add configuration to plans: Learn how to make your running service configurable by templatizing configuration files in your plan.
Cookbooks are Chef’s primary unit of configuration management. For tutorials on working with cookbooks in Chef, see Learn Chef Rally.

Chef Habitat Builder acts as the core of Chef’s Application Delivery Enterprise hub. You can run Chef Habitat Builder as a cloud-based service or on-premises.

EC2 Container Registry (ECR) is a fully-managed Docker registry provided by Amazon Web Services. Applications exported to Docker with hab pkg export docker put the containers into namespaced repositories, so you will need to create these within ECR. For example, if you were building core/mongodb containers you would use the following command:
AWS OpsWorks for Chef Automate is an AWS service which you can use to create a Chef Automate instance.
Azure Container Services (AKS) is a fully managed Kubernetes service running on the Azure platform.
A Journey with Chef Habitat on Amazon ECS, Part 1)
A Robust and Scalable Peer-to-Peer Gossiping Protocol by Spyros Voulgaris, Mark Jelasity, and Maarten van Steen.

Google Container Registry is a private Docker repository that works with popular continuous delivery systems. It runs on GCP to provide consistent uptime on an infrastructure protected by Google’s security. The registry service hosts your private images in Cloud Storage under your GCP project.
Chef Software Mailing List (for discussion among users, developers, and other interested parties)
Chef Automate | Chef InSpec | Chef Workstation | Chef Infra Client | Chef Infra Server | Chef Manage
Upload your Docker image to a supported registry. Your Docker repository should be match the origin/package identifier of your package.
Download Chef Workstation and run the installer on the developer machine. Accept the defaults.
Download the correct package for your operating system from downloads.chef.io.

Chef Automate - Chef Automate provides an Enterprise dashboard and analytics tool to enable cross-team collaboration with actionable insights for configuration and compliance, and an auditable history of environment changes.

Bento is a Chef Software project that produces base testing VirtualBox, Parallels, and VMware boxes for multiple operating systems for use with Test Kitchen. By default, Test Kitchen uses the base images provided by Bento although custom images may also be built using HashiCorp Packer.
Chef Infra - Chef Infra automates infrastructure configuration and ensures every system configures correctly and consistently.
Chef Infra - Chef Infra automates infrastructure configuration and ensures every system sets up correctly and consistently.
Stove is a cookbook release utility that keeps the upload process localized to the cookbook itself, as opposed to the Knife method which requires a cookbook repository.
Dex is a federated OpenID Connect (OIDC) provider that allows Automate to integrate with external identity providers via LDAP, SAML or OpenID Connect.
Chef Habitat - Chef Habitat codifies how the application builds, how it runs, and its dependencies to free the application from underlying infrastructure and make updates easy.
Chef InSpec - Chef InSpec automates security tests, and ensures enforcement of consistent standards in every environment and at every stage of development.
@juliandunn created a custom report handler that logs all of the cookbooks and cookbook versions that were used during a Chef Infra Client run, and then reports after the run is complete.
InstallApplications (plural) is a corresponding application that will install applications or settings during that stage of configuration.
InSpec-Iggy is a community InSpec plugin that generates InSpec compliance controls and profiles from Terraform tfstate files and AWS CloudFormation templates.
Download the whole Munki package to the macOS machine and install it.
Depnotify is an open source tool that tells users how much more time their macOS machine needs to install applications before they can starting using it.

Kubernetes is an open source container cluster manager that is available as a stand-alone platform or embedded in several distributed platforms including Google’s Container Engine, AWS Elastic Kubernetes Service, Azure Kubernetes Service, and Red Hat OpenShift. Chef Habitat and Kubernetes are complementary. While Kubernetes provides a platform for deployment, scaling, and operations of application containers across clusters of hosts, Chef Habitat manages the build pipeline and lifecycle of those application containers.
Apache Mesos is an open source distributed systems kernel and the distributed systems kernel for Mesosphere’s DC/OS distributed platform.

Marathon is a container orchestration platform for Mesos and DC/OS, handling the scheduling and deployment of applications. Marathon applications support Docker and the Mesos container formats, wrapping them in JSON metadata describing the resources needed to deploy the application. Once the application has been deployed to Marathon, it schedules it across the Mesos cluster and ensures the application is running optimally.
Kitchen Terraform is a community Test Kitchen driver that allows for multi-node testing.
Create an incoming webhook in Slack and be sure to use the team in Slack to be associated with Workflow.
Caffeinate keeps the desktop active so that the screensaver does not turn on during installation. The screensaver will turn off network connections and break the setup if it activates.
SWIM: Scalable Weakly-consistent Infection-style Process Group Membership Protocol by Abhinandan Das, Indranil Gupta, Ashish Motivala.
SWIM: Scalable Weakly-consistent Infection-style Process Group Membership Protocol by Abhinandan Das, Indranil Gupta, and Ashish Motivala.
hab sup run is the hab cli commant to start the Habitat supervisor.

Terraform is an open-source infrastructure-as-code provisioning tool from HashiCorp. Terraform allows you to write code to define and provision infrastructure for the cloud, virtual machines, and on-premises machines. Terraform is not a configuration management tool, it is responsible for deploying, maintaining, and destroying the infrastructure that servers and applications run on. When Terraform creates cloud or virtual servers, it uses Provisioners to enable configuration management to manage them. When Terraform talks to APIs to define or configure resources, it uses Providers to request those resources.

Upgrade Lab provides further details on how this command can be used in Chef Infra Client upgrade process.
"chef_oauth2_app_id" should contain the "uid" value from your OAuth credentials
"chef_oauth2_secret" should contain the "secret" value from your OAuth credentials

"chef_server_url" should contain the FQDN of your Chef Infra Server. Note that if you’re using a non-standard SSL port, this much be appended to the URL. For example: https://chefserver.mycompany.com:65400

"filters" Similar to the former Chef Push Jobs-based dispatch system, you can set a variety of filters. Filters control which runners can run a job for a Chef Automate project. You can set filters for the entire project as well as specific filters per phase. You can also specify a matrix of filters to a run phase job repeatedly on multiple platform configurations.
"name" and "clientname" are not independent values. Making a PUT request with different values will return a 400 error. Either name may be specified to set both values.
"ssm:*" uses a wildcard match on the AWS EC2 Systems Manager (SSM); You may wish to use a more restrictive policy.
"version" Set the value to “v2” if you wish to use runners and the new job dispatch system:
<CHANNEL> is the release channel to install from. See Chef Software Inc Packages for full details on the available channels.
<PRODUCT> is the Chef Software Inc product to install. A list of valid product keys can be found at https://github.com/chef/mixlib-install/blob/master/PRODUCT_MATRIX.md
<app_name> is the name of the project application
<app_version> is version number to which the project application is pinned
<value> can be specified as one of the following:
'/etc/motd' specifies the location in which the file is created
trans-unit.target: '/etc/motd' especifica la ubicación en la que se crea el archivo

trans-unit.source: '/tmp/something.ldif' specifies the location of the file
'/var/www/customers/public_html/index.html' is path to the file to be created
'/var/www/customers/public_html/index.php' is path to the file and also the filename to be managed
trans-unit.target: '/var/www/customers/public_html/index.php' es la ruta al archivo y también el nombre del archivo a administrar

trans-unit.source: '/var/www/customers/public_html/index.php' is path to the file to be created
trans-unit.target: '/var/www/customers/public_html/index.php' es la ruta al archivo que se creará

trans-unit.source: 'application_path' is the path to the application, such as '/myapp'
'attribute' is Hash of attributes associated with this version; each attribute is defined as a key-value pair: 'key = value'
'attribute' is a attribute in the pg hba configuration file
'attribute' is a attribute in the pg ident configuration file
'attribute' is a configuration parsed from result of the command ‘nginx -V’
'be_enabled' is an example of a valid matcher that checks the state of a task, other examples are exist or be_disabled
'command' must specify a command to be run
'domain' is a user or group name, such as grantmc
'expected value' tests the output of the command run on the system versus the expected output stated in the test
'file' is the path to a CSV file
'filter_value' is the value that is to be filtered for
'gids', 'groups', and 'users' are valid resource parameters for this resource.
'group_name' must specify the name of a group to be tested on the system
'http://somesite.com/index.html' specifies the location of the remote file, the file is downloaded from there
'http://somesite.com/index.php' specifies the location of the remote file
trans-unit.target: 'http://somesite.com/index.php' especifica la ubicación del archivo remoto

trans-unit.source: 'index.php' is a file in the /files directory in a cookbook that is used to create that file (the contents of the file in the cookbook will become the contents of the file on the node)
trans-unit.target: 'index.php' es un archivo en el directorio /files en un libro de cocina que se usa para crear ese archivo (el contenido del archivo en el libro de cocina se convertirá en el contenido del archivo en el nodo)

trans-unit.source: 'item' is the item for which limits are defined, such as core, nofile, stack, nproc, priority, or maxlogins

'kernel' specifies the default kernel (by using 'default') or a specific kernel; 'default' defines the position in the list of kernels at which the default kernel is defined, i.e. should eq '0' for the first kernel listed or 'path', 'default' to use the default kernel as specified in the grub.conf file
'kernel.parameter' must specify a kernel parameter, such as 'net.ipv4.conf.all.forwarding'
'keyword' is a configuration setting defined in the auditd.conf configuration file
'message' is the message that is logged.
'method' may be specified for http request method (default to ‘GET’)
'method' may be specified for http request method (default to ‘GET’).
'module_name' must specify a kernel module, such as 'bridge'
'motd.erb' specifies the name of a template that exists in in the /templates folder of a cookbook
trans-unit.target: 'motd.erb' especifica el nombre de una plantilla que existe en la carpeta /templates de un libro de cocina

trans-unit.source: 'name' is the name of the bonded network interface
'name' is the name of the package
'name' is the name of the package; this may be an array of packages
trans-unit.target: 'name' es el nombre del paquete; esto puede ser una variedad de paquetes

trans-unit.source: 'name' is the unique name for the control_group; the chef-client will raise an exception if duplicate control_group names are present
trans-unit.target: 'name' es el nombre único para el grupo de control_group ; el chef-cliente generará una excepción si hay nombres duplicados de control_group

trans-unit.source: 'output' tests the output of the command run on the system versus the output value stated in the test
'package_name' is the name of the package, such as 'DBD::Pg'
'package_name' is the name of the package, such as 'DBI'
'package_name' is the name of the package, such as 'Jinja2'
'parameter' is a comma-separated list, each specifying a platform family, such as Debian, or Red Hat Enterprise Linux
trans-unit.target: 'parameter' es una lista separada por comas, cada una de las cuales especifica una familia de plataformas, como Debian o Red Hat Enterprise Linux

trans-unit.source: 'parameter' must be a valid parameter defined within this resource ie logon_mode, last_result, task_to_run, run_as_user
'path' is the path to the grub.conf file
'path' is the path to your Postfix configuration (ex. ‘/etc/my/postfix/path/main.cf’)
'platform', ... is a comma-separated list of platforms, such as Red Hat, openSUSE, or Fedora
trans-unit.target: 'platform', ... es una lista de plataformas separadas por comas, como Red Hat, openSUSE o Fedora

trans-unit.source: 'platform_family' => 'value', ... is a comma-separated list of platforms, such as Fedora, openSUSE, or Red Hat Enterprise Linux
'platform_family' => { 'version' => 'value' }, ... is a comma-separated list of platforms, such as Fedora, openSUSE, or Red Hat Enterprise Linux
trans-unit.target: 'platform_family' => { 'version' => 'value' }, ... es una lista de plataformas separadas por comas, como Fedora, openSUSE o Red Hat Enterprise Linux

trans-unit.source: 'query' is a valid search query against an object on the Chef Infra Server (see below for more information about how to build the query)
'query' is a valid search query against an object on the Chef server
trans-unit.target: 'query' es una consulta de búsqueda válida contra un objeto en el servidor Chef

trans-unit.source: 'query' is a valid search query against an object on the Chef server (see below for more information about how to build the query)
trans-unit.target: 'query' es una consulta de búsqueda válida contra un objeto en el servidor Chef (consulte a continuación para obtener más información sobre cómo generar la consulta)

trans-unit.source: 'redhat', 'centos' will install Apache using the httpd package and 'ubuntu', 'debian' will install it using the apache2 package
'script' must specify a Powershell script to be run
'script_name' is the name of the VBScript to test
'selection_lines' refers to all selection lines found in the aide.conf file
'service_name' is a service listed in the grub.conf file
'service_name' is a service listed in the inetd.conf file
'setting' specifies a setting in the my.cnf file, such as max_connections
'setting' specifies a setting in the postgresql.conf file
'setting_name' is a configuration setting defined in the Apache configuration file
'setting_name' is a setting key defined in main.cf
'setting_name' is a setting key defined in the INI file
'setting_name' is a synchronization setting defined in the ntp.conf file
'setting_name' is description of the Apache configuration file
'site_name' is the name of the site, such as 'Default Web Site'
'slapadd < /tmp/something.ldif' is the command that is run
trans-unit.target: 'slapadd < /tmp/something.ldif' es el comando que se ejecuta

trans-unit.source: 'something.ldif' specifies template file from which /tmp/something.ldif is created
trans-unit.target: 'something.ldif' especifica el archivo de plantilla a partir del cual se crea /tmp/something.ldif

trans-unit.source: 'sshd-8' is the name of the control
'value' is the value associated with the item
'value' is the value that is expected
'value' is the value that is expected of the attribute
'value' is the value that is to be matched expected
'value' is the value to be tested
'value' is the value to be tested.
'value' must be one of No Auditing, Not Specified, Success, Success and Failure, or Failure
'value' will be used to compare the value gather from your chosen parameter
('VARIABLE') must specify an environment variable, such as PATH
('app_pool_name') is the name of the application pool in which the site’s root application is run, such as 'DefaultAppPool'
('application_pool') is the name of the application pool in which the site’s root application is run, such as 'DefaultAppPool'
('binding_details') is a binding for the site, such as 'net.pipe *'. A site may have multiple bindings; therefore, use a have_binding matcher for each site binding to be tested
('class') is the WMI class to which the setting belongs, such as win32_service
('dataset') is the name of the ZFS dataset (eg: 'tank/tmp')
('feature_name') must specify a Windows feature name, such as DHCP Server or IIS-Webserver
('gem_binary') can specify the path to a non-default gem binary, defaults to 'gem'
('gem_package_name') must specify a Gem package, such as 'rubocop'
('name') must specify the (case-sensitive) name of a package, such as 'nssm'
('name') must specify the name of a firewall profile, such as 'Public', 'Private' or 'Domain'
('name') must specify the name of a firewall rule, which is not the firewall rule’s display name
('name') must specify the name of a hotfix, such as 'KB4012213'
('name') must specify the name of a package, such as 'VLC'
('name') must specify the name of a package, such as 'nginx'
('namespace') is path to that object, such as root\\cimv2
('npm_package_name') must specify an NPM package, such as 'bower' or 'statsd'
('output') is the expected output of the VBScript
('path') is the name of the file and/or the path to the file.
('path') is the non-default path to the aide.conf file (optional)
('path') is the non-default path to the auditd.conf configuration file
('path') is the non-default path to the inetd.conf file
('path') is the non-default path to the my.cnf file
('path') is the non-default path to the ntp.conf file
('path') is the non-default path to the postgresql.conf file (optional)
('path') is the non-default path to the Apache configuration file
('path') is the path to the INI file
('path') is the path to the mounted directory
('path') may be an http:// address, a ppa: address, or a short repo-name/ppa address
('path_to_site') is the path to the site, such as 'C:\\inetpub\\wwwroot'
('physical_path') is the physical path to the application, such as 'C:\\inetpub\\wwwroot\\myapp'
('pool') is the name of the ZFS pool (eg: 'tank')
('protocols') is a binding for the site, such as 'http'. A site may have multiple bindings; therefore, use a have_protocol matcher for each site protocol to be tested
('root') is the user to be tested
('setting') is a setting in the xinetd.conf file
('setting_name') is a setting in the WMI object to be tested, and then should eq '' is the expected value for that setting
('system') is the name of the system information of the virtualization platform (e.g. docker, lxc, vbox, kvm, etc)
(pid 1486) 7819s; is the process identifier followed by the amount of time (in seconds) the service has been running
trans-unit.target: (pid 1486) 7819s; es el identificador de proceso seguido de la cantidad de tiempo (en segundos) que el servicio ha estado ejecutándose

trans-unit.source: ** matches the current directory and arbitrary subdirectories. This sequence must form a single path component, so both **a and b** are invalid. More than two consecutive * characters is also invalid.
* will match any (possibly empty) sequence of characters
--airgap, --no-airgap Fallback to using local archives if fetching fails.
--attrs=one two three Legacy name for –input-file - deprecated.
--backend-cache, --no-backend-cache Allow caching for backend command output. (default: true)
--bastion-host=BASTION_HOST Specifies the bastion host if applicable
--bastion-port=BASTION_PORT Specifies the bastion port if applicable
--bastion-user=BASTION_USER Specifies the bastion user if applicable
--chef-license <value> argument passed to the command line invocation.
--config=CONFIG Read configuration from JSON file (- reads from stdin).
--connection-password: for Linux hosts, the password to use during bootstrap
--controls=one two three A list of control names to run, or a list of /regexes/ to match against control names. Ignore all other tests.
--controls=one two three A list of controls to include. Ignore all other tests.
--create-lockfile, --no-create-lockfile Write out a lockfile based on this execution (unless one already exists)
--depends=one two three A space-delimited list of local folders containing profiles whose libraries and resources will be loaded into the new shell
--distinct-exit, --no-distinct-exit Exit with code 100 if any tests fail, and 101 if any are skipped but none failed (default). If disabled, exit 0 on skips and 1 for failures.
--distinct-exit, --no-distinct-exit Exit with code 101 if any tests fail, and 100 if any are skipped (default). If disabled, exit 0 on skips and 1 for failures.
--enable-password=ENABLE_PASSWORD Password for enable mode on Cisco IOS devices.
--format c sets the output to PostgreSQL’s “custom” binary file format
--host=HOST Specify a remote host which is tested.
--input-file=one two three Load one or more input files, a YAML file with values for the profile to use
--input=name1=value1 name2=value2 Specify one or more inputs directly on the command line, as –input NAME=VALUE. Accepts single-quoted YAML and JSON structures.
--insecure, --no-insecure Disable SSL verification on select targets
--lease-days: number of days for the resource lease
--notes: any optional notes you’d like to be logged with your request
--overwrite, --no-overwrite Overwrite existing vendored dependencies and lockfile.
--password=PASSWORD Login password for a remote scan, if required.
--path=PATH Login path to use when connecting to the target (WinRM).
--proxy-command=PROXY_COMMAND Specifies the command to use to connect to the server
--publish-address and/or --vip-interface are specified, but a non-empty chef-backend.rb file already exists. (This command will not overwrite a chef-backend.rb file.)
--reporter-backtrace-inclusion, --no-reporter-backtrace-inclusion Include a code backtrace in report data (default: true)
--reporter-message-truncation=REPORTER_MESSAGE_TRUNCATION Number of characters to truncate failure messages in report data to (default: no truncation)
--reporter=one two:/output/file/path Enable one or more output reporters: cli, documentation, html, progress, json, json-min, json-rspec, junit
--reporter=one two:/output/file/path Enable one or more output reporters: cli, documentation, html, progress, json, json-min, json-rspec, junit, yaml
--requested-for: vRA login that should be listed as the owner
--self-signed, --no-self-signed Allow remote scans with self-signed certificates (WinRM).
--shell-command=SHELL_COMMAND Specify a particular shell to use.
--shell, --no-shell Run scans in a subshell. Only activates on Unix.
--silence-deprecations=all|GROUP GROUP... Suppress deprecation warnings. See install_dir/etc/deprecations.json for list of GROUPs or use ‘all’.
--ssl, --no-ssl Use SSL for transport layer encryption (WinRM).

--subtenant-id: all resources must be tied back to a Business Group, or “subtenant.” If your catalog item is tied to a specific Business Group, you do not need to specify this. However, if your catalog item is a global catalog item, then the subtenant ID is not available to knife; you will need to provide it. It usually looks like a UUID. See your vRA administrator for assistance in determining your subtenant ID.
--sudo-options=SUDO_OPTIONS Additional sudo options for a remote scan.
--sudo-password=SUDO_PASSWORD Specify a sudo password, if it is required.
--sudo ensures that sudo is used while running commands on the node during the bootstrap operation
--sudo, --no-sudo Run scans with sudo. Only activates on Unix and non-root user.
--target-id=TARGET_ID Provide a ID which will be included on reports
--user=USER The login user for a remote scan.
--vendor-cache=VENDOR_CACHE Use the given path for caching dependencies. (default: ~/.inspec/cache)
--waiver-file=one two three Load one or more waiver files.
--winrm-basic-auth-only, --no-winrm-basic-auth-only Whether to use basic authentication, defaults to false (WinRM).
--winrm-disable-sspi, --no-winrm-disable-sspi Whether to use disable sspi authentication, defaults to false (WinRM).
--winrm-password: for Windows hosts, the password to use during bootstrap
--winrm-transport=WINRM_TRANSPORT Specify which transport to use, defaults to negotiate (WinRM).
-N defines the name of the Chef Supermarket node: supermarket-node
-b, --backend=BACKEND Choose a backend: local, ssh, winrm, docker.
-c, --command=COMMAND A single command string to run instead of launching the shell
-f FILE_NAME writes the USER.pem to a file instead of STDOUT. For example: /tmp/grantmc.key.
-f FILE_NAME: Write the ORGANIZATION-validator.pem to FILE_NAME instead of printing it to STDOUT. For example: /tmp/chef.key.
-f FILE_NAME: Write the ORGANIZATION-validator.pem to FILE_NAME instead of printing it to STDOUT. For example: /tmp/chef.key.
trans-unit.target: -f FILE_NAME : escriba ORGANIZATION-validator.pem en FILE_NAME en lugar de imprimirlo en STDOUT . Por ejemplo: /tmp/chef.key .

trans-unit.source: -i, --key-files=one two three Login key or certificate file for a remote scan.
